Who is going to pay the difference? Of course it will be the patient.

So the Labor Party is strongly opposed to part 5 of this bill because it will increase the costs to patients. It will also increase the costs of private health insurance. If contracts are entered into between private medical specialists and health funds at a rate of 130 per cent of the schedule fee, who do we think is going to pay? It will be those who take out private health insurance. The increase in costs that will mean for the individuals, for the health funds and for the health system as a whole is certainly a very strong reason for opposing this part. Labor certainly does oppose it and will do so here today and in the Senate.

The second reason for opposing it is that we are not at all clear—and the minister may like to comment on this; I will be pleased to hear his response—about how the minister intends quality control be monitored and high standards of medical practice in these office based services be ensured if part 5 is successful. We do have a very good system of control to monitor quality in day surgery. I would be interested to hear from the minister how he intends to make sure that accreditation and quality control happens if part 5 comes into fruition.

talk.start.para: —I do not intend to get into a lengthy debate on individual points. Clearly the forms of the House allow the opposition to say what they wish as often as they wish. Just to answer those points, I could not expect a party full of union officials to understand how business works. This will only happen if it is in the financial interests of the health insurance fund. If a fund can save a day in hospital at $400 to $500 by paying a doctor a few dollars extra, that is a whole net saving to the fund and hence to the premium.

speech.para: Far from fees going up, fees will go down if anything, although, to be fair, what I think it would do is lower the rate of increase. I would not be as silly as the former health minister, Dr Lawrence, to suggest that these sorts of measures would make premiums go down, as she suggested at the National Press Club in 1995. Far from being a cost to funds, it is likely to be a benefit and to encourage the most appropriate care.

It is interesting that the Labor Party should be talking about increasing the cost of premiums when part of the problem here is the very decision they themselves made to take rebates from 85 per cent to 75 per cent for in-hospital care and to whack the other cost directly onto the health funds. That was quite unreasonable at the time. That led to price inflation and there were no trade-offs. The whole point is that there is a trade-off.
Ms Macklin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is a trade-off. You can interject and you can giggle, but the fact is that a fund does not have to enter a contract unless it is in its interests to do so. History shows that that is exactly what will happen.

speech.para: The second point relates to quality, which has been an issue of concern to me. We have very challenging issues across the whole of the health care sector relating to quality. There is no simple solution because it is very difficult to regulate the day-to-day, hour-to-hour or minute-to-minute practice of a wide variety of doctors. It can only be done cooperatively.

We did announce in the last election, and I would expect we would be funding in this budget, a national institute of clinical studies. That was designed specifically to look at issues of quality across the whole of the health care sector to find a way of driving cost-effective, high quality health care. The two are not mutually exclusively; there is very good evidence from overseas that good quality medicine costs you less rather than more. We hope to deal with these issues in that manner, but it is no easy task. Nor is the problem solved in in-hospital care.

Amendment (by Dr Wooldridge) proposed:
(1) Schedule 1, Part 6, page 15 (lines 2 to 31), omit the Part.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports this amendment because it is removing part 6 of this piece of legislation. This legislation was introduced in December last year by the current minister after apparently no consultation whatsoever with the AMA. The AMA, when they got to look at the bill, were understandably concerned that they had not been consulted, given that the purpose of this part of the bill was to radically change the way in which health insurance would apply to out-of-hospital specialist services.

speech.para: The minister met with the AMA two days later. I understand he took the issue back to cabinet and, what do you know—they agreed that this part of the bill could be removed because the AMA did not like it. So as for which members of parliament respond to the pressures of union officials, Minister, I would have to say that the evidence in the debate that we are having right now would lend support to the notion that the Liberal and National parties are the ones that respond when the AMA says jump.

Nevertheless, it is the opposition's view that this would have been a very dangerous extension. It is interesting that the minister seems very happy with everything that is in part 5. Part 6 is, of course, just an extension of part 5. Part 5 is all about enabling private health insurance to cover certain office based procedures delivered by specialists in their rooms. Part 6 is about allowing specialists of any type to have private health insurance coverage if they enter into contracts with private health insurers. The same arguments apply in part 6 as apply in part 5.

We should all be aware that this is what the government wants to see happen. The government does not have a fundamental commitment to Medicare because, if it did, it would be trying to strengthen the role of the medical benefit schedule in keeping costs down. What this government wants to do, which has not been done since the introduction of Medicare, is extend private health insurance to cover specialist procedures and specialist services outside of hospital.

Australia has been successful at keeping down its health spending because of the role the medical benefit schedule has played in making sure that, in the main, specialists keep to that schedule. It is the great success of the Australian health system that we have a medical benefit schedule that most doctors adhere to. That is particularly the case with general practitioners, but even a large number of specialists adhere to the medical benefit schedule. Not many specialists overcharge. The ones that do certainly do so dramatically and hurt their patients. Those who do the right thing and keep within the bounds of the schedule ensure that patients are protected.

This government has flagged to the community—though not today, because they are moving to remove this part—that they would like to see private health insurance cover specialist fees. That is so specialists can go out there and negotiate contracts to any level whatsoever. There is no cap in the bill and there is no suggestion that it should be at 100 per cent of the schedule fee or 130 per cent of the schedule fee. It is whatever the private health insurers might like to pay doctors.

Concerning this idea that, as the minister says, it will only happen if it is in the interests of the private health insurance funds, nothing could be further from the truth. The experience in Australia is that, if private hospitals and doctors say, `We need more money,' then the health insurers just say yes and write the cheque. That is why we have had a massive explosion of cost to private health insurance. There is no experience either here or in the United States that, without strong controls by a national government to make sure that the cost of medical services are contained, we will not see medical fee inflation. The action of this government, in indicating to the public that they want to extend private health insurance, only means that costs will rise. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The government is seeking to delete this section but for very different reasons than the opposition. We do not have government by agreement with unions or other interest groups. We flagged this change in the middle of last year. We did not feel that we needed the AMA's or anybody else's agreement. The AMA may be aggrieved about the process—people are aggrieved about processes from time to time—but the nature of government is that you have the right to make decisions. The AMA put to me that this would be highly divisive within the medical profession, that it would jeopardise a number of other things on which we are working cooperatively. In the whole scheme of things, it is not of great moment. I thought it was very much in the longer term interests that we should attempt to work cooperatively and that is why I was happy to remove it.

speech.para: The shadow minister has made a number of comments: that the schedule keeps costs down, that the increase in private health insurance costs have somehow been related to the payment of above schedule fees. While the schedule may keep unit costs down, it does nothing on volume. Naturally, the unit cost times volume is the cost to government. When we came to government, the Medicare benefits schedule, at about $5 billion, was out of control after 13 years under Labor.

Certainly areas like pathology and radiology were growing at unsustainable rates. Ultrasounds were increasing over 20 per cent per annum compound. Pathology was something that we had no control over, and these are very large parts of the schedule—well over $1 billion. They have come under control in recent years, not by nature of the schedule but by nature of cooperative work with those parts of the medical profession.

I find it very interesting to go back to what the previous health minister, the member for Fremantle, was saying in 1995 when she passed legislation to allow health funds to contract with doctors for in-hospital services. It was oversold. She did say that this would bring fees down. Now the same party is arguing that a minor extension would push increased costs. That is a completely contradictory argument and you cannot get away with it. If we have had an explosion in costs in health insurance, it is because of years of neglect.

The Productivity Commission shows very clearly why that is so. The first reason is that we have a different product. It has gone from being a product that gave you choice of treatment in a public or private hospital, to being a product where you buy private insurance in private hospitals, so that it is more expensive. The second reason is adverse selection. Again, you get into a bit of a spiral: older, sicker people stay in while younger, fitter people drop out. Neither of these has anything whatsoever to do with above schedule costs. The Labor Party is simply wrong there.

We were hoping to take away a disincentive for doctors to choose one form of treatment over another. It seems fundamentally silly when, for example, a doctor can do a gastroscopy—a very simple procedure today—in a hospital and the patient can be reimbursed 100 per cent of the scheduled fee, or they can do it in their rooms and the patient is reimbursed only 85 per cent of the scheduled fee. Fifteen years ago, they would have been done only in hospitals. That, clearly, is silly. It is ludicrous. Changes to medicine have outpaced the Medicare benefits schedule. In the whole scheme of things, it is not a massive change. It is something the government was prepared to remove. That is basically the reason why we are seeking to do it.

talk.start.para: —The minister is trying to play down this very significant change which, from the information that has been made public, certainly seemed to run very fast on a meeting that he had with the AMA. The minister would also know that this move to extend private health insurance to cover out-of-hospital medical services does absolutely nothing to contain the volume of services. If there is any experience in Australia of private health insurers playing a role to control the volume of services, I would like to know about it. I have never heard of any examples of that happening in the Australian situation.

speech.para: We have extensive examples of that happening now in the United States of America. The reason it is happening in the United States is that they faced a situation of massive medical fee inflation, driving up the costs of private health insurance and of health care in that country. What was the response of the private health insurers in the United States of America to this massive medical fee inflation, which this minister wants to open up in the Australian situation? The response of the private health insurers in the United States has been to introduce managed care to control volume.

That is exactly what they want to do, and I have no doubt that the minister knows all about it. Certainly the other groups in Australia that knows all about it are the doctors and the patients. The one thing doctors and patients certainly agree about in Australia is that they do not want a US style of managed care to intervene, to have a group of health insurers deciding what medical procedures a person will or will not get as the only way in which health funding in Australia can be contained.

Australians want to know that when they go to the doctor they are not going to have to pay through the nose. If the government is unwilling to contain medical fee inflation and wants to encourage the increase in the costs of going to the doctor—because of the sorts of measures we are debating today—the direct result of the changes to the private health insurance sector and the private medical system in Australia will be managed care. It will be the only way in which health costs can be contained.

From Labor's point of view, that is not the way that we would like Australia's health system go. I agree with the minister on the point that it is a good idea to do as many procedures and to deliver as many services as possible outside of hospitals. Which are the hospitals that are under the most pressure in the Australian health system? Of course, they are the public hospitals. Let us make some changes to medical practice, general practice and specialist practice that make it in the interests of doctors and patients to do things outside hospitals for the vast majority of patients that do not have private health insurance. They are not going to be able to afford to buy the new product that will be created as a result of this bill, and they certainly will not be able to do so when it drives up the costs of medical services.

Labor certainly does not agree with the direction that this minister has in mind. It is a very radical change; it is not a minor change. He is trying to say, `Don't anybody worry; don't anybody have too close a look at it.' It is high time we all had a very close look at it. It will have a dramatic impact on the costs of going to a doctor in Australia. We now know the minister's true agenda: he wants to extend private health insurance into areas that previously have been covered only by Medicare. And it should stay that way.

talk.start.para: —I really have to respond to that rhetoric without any intellectual basis behind it. The shadow minister goes from talking about volume in the Medicare benefits schedule to talking about volume in private health insurance—two totally different concepts—and merges the two. So the fundamental basis of her argument was incorrect in the first place.

speech.para: She then talks about fee inflation in the United States being the thing that drove up health care costs. That is incorrect; it is technology that drove up health care costs. It is the uncontrolled supply side of health care, both in physicians and in technology—which we have addressed and which the Labor Party have opposed, as they have opposed every major change we have tried to do in health. So it is hospital costs, technology costs, doctor numbers and CT scanner numbers that are driving health care costs in the United States, not fee inflation by doctors. The shadow minister talks about this dramatically increasing the cost of going to doctors. It is just rhetoric; it is rubbish. If anything, it would reduce the cost because it would have covered some out-of-pocket expenses.

Then she makes the leap that this is somehow managed care, seeming to attempt to divorce herself totally, which she cannot do, from what the Labor Party did in 1995. On becoming minister, I was able to find out the motives for much of the legislation that had been passed. I was able to find out the motives for the coordinated care trials. I was able to find out the unspoken agenda of the previous government. In fact, what she is accusing us of a psychiatrist would call `projection', in that it was the agenda of the Labor Party but they never had the honesty to talk to the Australian people and medical profession about it.

Yes, the public hospitals are under pressure, but just because they are under pressure does not mean that we cannot look at some other part of the health care system. We have signed health care agreements with the states to provide increases in public hospital funding unimaginable to the Labor Party—by far the greatest one-off increase in public hospital funding ever.

If hospitals are under pressure, you have to look at why they are under pressure. There are two reasons: firstly, the nature of the agreement that the Labor Party signed with the states in 1993, where there was a big one-off increase in funding up-front to get the states to sign off, with very flat funding for the next five years—and so, at the end of the five-year agreement, the hospitals are under pressure. The second reason was that the states drew money out after the Commonwealth put extra money in. The extra money the Commonwealth put in was a sleight of hand—they took money out of the financial assistance grants to the states and put it into the health budget. So the net effect was that the states were not much better off.

We have been able to address both of those things in a way the Labor Party was never able to in government. It will mean that, over time, the states can address their issues of concern to public hospitals. But having done that—having found the extra resources and having won the agreement—we now have to look at other aspects of the health care system, and the two are separate. The fact is the Labor Party is rooted back in 1984. A former member for Jagajaga, Brian Howe, said that if Medicare does not evolve—

talk.start.para: —He was the member for Batman.

—Batman, I am sorry. I was thinking that he formerly held your seat, but he is just your mentor. If Medicare does not evolve, it dies. The fact is that health care is changing. What was done in hospitals in 1984 is now done routinely in rooms in 1999. It is a different health care system, and this is seeking to keep up with that but really no more.

—When going over this issue of medical fee inflation, the minister might like to have a look at the experience in the United States before managed care really took hold and look at the levels of medical fee inflation. I understand, looking at some recent data from the United States, that they are very concerned that it is about to break out again.

speech.para: I will also remind the House of how we came to have gap coverage of 100 per cent of the schedule fee in private health insurance. It was a resolution of the New South Wales doctors dispute to give equal coverage to public and private patients and to get rid of gaps for the private patients. Of course, this did not happen. That was not the result of the decision to go to 100 per cent of the schedule fee. What in fact happened was that the doctors concerned took the 100 per cent and then charged extra on top of that.

The experience all around the world is that if you offer gap insurance, it is just an invitation to put up the fee. It is very likely that we would now see that as a result of the contracts that have been signed because of this minister's changes to the legislation. I understand that the sorts of contracts that have been signed in some hospitals in Australia are offering specialists 130 per cent of the schedule fee. So we have now gone from specialists being paid 100 per cent of the schedule fee to their being paid 130 per cent of the schedule fee if they are prepared to enter into contracts. The implications of that for the cost of private health insurance are very significant indeed. That is why Labor will continue to oppose any shift of private health insurance into community based medical care, not because we do not want to increase the activity that happens in the community; we do. If it is a good idea, let us do it as part of Medicare.

talk.start.para: —That is just complete rubbish. The fact is that the one fund that has been signing almost all the agreements, HBA in Victoria or Mutual Community in South Australia, seems to think that this is going to bring their costs down. When the legislation was originally passed by Dr Lawrence, if you go back and read the questions and answers given at the National Press Club in 1995, she said, `Let's be frank; this will bring doctors' fees down.' So that is what Dr Lawrence argued it would do in 1995, and in 1999 the shadow minister argues completely the opposite. You cannot have it both ways. You cannot have your hollow rhetoric in 1995 to meet a political end and then argue 180 degrees differently in 1999. If it was good enough for Dr Lawrence then, it is good enough now.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes this item as well. It is only necessary because of the changes the government is introducing as part of its extension of private health insurance to out-of-hospital care.

Schedule 2, item 9.

talk.start.para: —The opposition opposes this item as well. This is one of the most confused elements of what I would have to say is a very confused bill. It varies the requirement that the health funds must include, within any contract for the provision of hospital care, coverage for treatment in respect of palliative care, psychiatric care or rehabilitation care. This is a very important requirement which protects the interests of older people, and it certainly would be very wrong for insurance policies to be written to include a range of services that are used by people of all ages. Some health funds might craftily exclude precisely those services which are most frequently used by older people. It certainly would be significant discrimination against older Australians and would undermine the principle of community rating that protects the most vulnerable in the community from being excluded from the shared coverage that universal insurance provides.

speech.para: The government actually seemed confused about what they were trying to achieve by permitting for the first time palliative care, psychiatric care and rehabilitation care to be excluded from coverage. The explanatory memorandum certainly gives no rationale for this measure. In the Senate Community Affairs Legislation Committee, the expert witness from the Department of Health and Aged Care denied any knowledge of the provision and testified that there was nothing in the bill that dealt with the exclusion of these classes of services. Nevertheless, it is referred to in the explanatory memorandum. The official who made that point is certainly wrong. It seems as if the department did not know what was in its own bill.

The opposition is of the view that there should be no such exclusion and will therefore oppose this item. We would like to see the deletion of the objectionable provision by which older people could be victimised by the exclusion of the categories of service that they rely on from policies which provide coverage for office based services at approved facilities. The government has been asked to explain its position, and it came back with the view that part 5 is intended to provide for treatment. The minister has made it very clear today that part 5 is about providing for treatment in out-of-hospital settings as a substitute for in-hospital care—something that we certainly agree with. The government envisages that this cover would be provided in conjunction with hospital cover, but that is not required by the legislation—in fact, the opposite is permitted. As I read the legisla tion, the private health insurance funds will be able to offer a policy that is just about covering people for out-of-hospital specialist procedures. Of course, if the government gets its way, those particular policies will not have to cover palliative care, rehab or psychiatric care.

The choice of whether to offer those particular areas—palliative care, psychiatric care and rehab—in a lower cost setting would be left to the fund on the understanding that it would remain a compulsory requirement to provide these services in conjunction with any hospital insurance. I have to say that this is hopelessly convoluted and fails to recognise the importance of these services and the financial incentive to the funds to find a way to deny older people this type of coverage. It certainly is going to see a very significant opening of the stable door in the false belief that the horses—the private health insurance funds—have no desire to bolt. This door should remain firmly shut and the opportunity to disaggregate an expensive group of services to give some people discounts at the expense of adequate care for older Australians should be denied.

The government should accept that it has not understood the consequences of what it proposes and that this is a mistake in what I admit is a very technical area. I look forward to the government reconsidering its position and accepting that it needs to remove this item.

talk.start.para: —I accept that it is highly technical and so I forgive the opposition for getting confused. The fact is that we were more than willing to put psych, rehab and palliative care in hospital tables, and we argued the case for that before the Productivity Commission. I think they are areas where you can put an argument that there is a real issue of potential market failure and that these would be unlikely to be covered unless it was mandated to do so. But just because someone is not better off does not mean, conversely, that they are worse off. The default position is the current position, that they are covered by Medicare, so no-one is worse off. It is not logical to me to extend that into surgery based services when it is still a requirement in hospital based services where nearly all of this is carried out.

—There is nothing in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1998 that talks about surgery. It talks about professional services. The bill talks in part 5 about office based professional services. And then in the explanatory memorandum it specifically mentions that funds will be allowed to offer policies that exclude palliative, psychiatric and rehab care. Maybe the Minister for Health and Aged Care does not want to deal with this in the House today, but I hope that by the time the issue reaches the Senate the government will have had a rethink and made sure that the bill in its form in the Senate does not include this pernicious attack on the needs of older Australians.

—Far from being a pernicious attack on older Australians, the fact is that the government met its responsibilities. The government sought to require the funds to cover psych, rehab and palliative care, and not just for older people. Psychiatric services are used extensively by younger people, and my concern 2½ years ago was to ensure that younger people would not be disadvantaged by losing access to psychiatric care. So it does affect the whole community, not just older people as the shadow minister is attempting to point out. I believe she is wrong. I believe people are more than adequately covered. As a small gesture of goodwill, I will recheck, but I am confident that the status quo with respect to hospital services where all these services are carried out with private health insurance is maintained.

—There is no suggestion that it changes the hospital based cover. That is not the point. The point of this item is that it enables the new policies that health funds will be allowed to offer—that is, health policies that cover only out-of-hospital, office based services—to exclude palliative care, psychiatric care and rehabilitation care. Of course, a lot of that happens outside hospitals, and so it should. I have no doubt that the minister thinks that is a good idea, as I do. So we certainly do not want those things excluded if the government gets its way and part 5 comes to pass.
—The shadow minister seems to misunderstand that the default situation is the status quo, which is what we have got now, and no-one is worse off.

speech.para: Item agreed to.
Schedule 2 agreed to.
Schedule 3, items 1 to 3—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 3, items 4 and 5—by leave—taken together.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (16) Schedule 3, page 20 (lines 28 to 31), omit paragraph 78(4)(d).
(17) Schedule 3, page 22 (lines 16 to 18), omit paragraph 78A(8)(d).

The purpose of these amendments is to change the way in which the minister's powers are defined with regard to what he might or might not do when he considers rule changes to private health insurance.

One of the things which we all have responsibility as members of parliament to do is, of course, to make our decisions in the public interest. The bill makes it clear that, with regard to any changes that the minister might make to private health insurance rules, he would be making those in the public interest. Certainly, as far as that part of the bill is concerned, we agree.

It then goes on to say that the minister should consider the interests of the industry. The important thing for any health minister to have as his or her primary responsibility is the interests of the public. The interests of the public should be the overriding and only interest that any government should have in mind when considering changes to the rules for private health insurance.

With regard to the idea that ministers take into account the interests of the industry, in many instances, these may conflict with the interests of the public. For example, the interests of the industry might suggest that it would be a good idea to reduce competition between the health insurance funds. That would dramatically conflict with the interests of those who hold private health insurance. From Labor's point of view, it is very important that the minister's primary and only responsibility, when considering rule changes, be only those things that are in the public interest.

talk.start.para: —The government opposes these amendments. The net effect of them is actually to increase the minister's power. Clearly, as minister, one acts in the public interest. If you do not, the public has a chance to comment on that every couple of years in an election. The real effect of these amendments, by being able to look at the whole industry, is that I would be able to take wider views into account, so it strengthens my capacity, which at the moment is extraordinarily limited.

speech.para: Amendments negatived.
Items agreed to.
Schedule 3, items 6 and 7—by leave—taken together, and agreed to.
Schedule 3, items 8 to 18—by leave—taken together.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will certainly strongly oppose these items. This minister is really trying to wriggle out from any responsibility for any future increases in private health insurance premiums. We have seen, just in the last week or so, a massive increase—a 22 per cent average increase—in private health insurance premiums for the Defence Force insurance fund. This 22 per cent premium increase is the first increase we have seen since the government's introduction of its health insurance rebate.

speech.para: The minister gaily approved this massive increase. What he wants to do now is remove any responsibility whatsoever for any future increases. Maybe he knows a bit more than we or the public do; maybe he knows that the sorts of increases that will be sought over the next couple of years by the health insurance funds are very significant, and he wants to distance himself and the Prime Minister from any of those increases. Of course, he will not be able to, even if he plays no role, because the opposition will be making it very clear that he has walked away from any responsibility in this regard.

As a result of the government getting through its 30 per cent health insurance rebate, whenever health funds put their health insurance premiums up by as much as 22 per cent, who do you think will be paying 30 per cent of that massive increase in health insurance costs? Thirty per cent of the increase in health insurance costs will be paid for by the taxpayer, because of this government's brilliant idea with regard to health insurance rebates—just an open-ended cheque by this government of taxpayers' money, with no accountability whatsoever by this minister.

This item seeks to remove any shadow of responsibility which this government might have had for private health insurance premium rises. The taxpayer is going to be paying 30 per cent, but who pays the 70 per cent? Who pays the vast majority of any increase in private health insurance premiums? Of course, it is the individual who has the premium.

Some of those defence health fund members who saw their premiums go up by 22 per cent just last week have gone backwards. Not only have they paid an increase of 22 per cent on their premiums but also they lost the targeted health insurance rebate, which was the government's first attempt to support the funds. Individuals are having to pay 70 per cent of any increase, because $7 out of every $10 by which health insurance goes up is paid for by the person who has health insurance.

Does this minister want to take any responsibility for that? Not one bit. He does not want to take any responsibility for the fact that he is allocating a huge amount of taxpayers' money every time health insurance premiums go up. He does not want to take any responsibility for the fact that, every time health insurance premiums go up, people are going to be out of pocket. This is the most blatant example of any minister walking away from his responsibilities to those who have private health insurance. The opposition will certainly oppose this measure.

talk.start.para: —I present the supplementary memorandum. The government does not agree with the opposition's point of view. History is illustrative. How many premium increases do you think the Labor Party varied between 1984 and 1996? The answer is: not one. Every single premium increase went through without even the minister examining it. If you look at the Labor Party's track record in government, you find that it simply let the funds do what they liked. It is very easy to stand up and be critical but it is also incumbent on you, if you are going to criticise, to offer some sort of alternative. That is, of course, what the opposition never does. There is never any alternative offered.

speech.para: In relation to the defence health fund, which did have a large premium increase, in their wisdom they chose not to increase their premiums in 1998. I do not know why they did not do so but they did have a relatively low premium. They had higher drawings and higher claims than expected and the fact is that, without that increase, the fund would have gone broke. I put it to the shadow minister: what would you have done? The alternative would be to let the fund go broke. The alternative would be to do what the Labor Party did for 13 years in government, and that is allow every one to go through without any examination whatsoever.

We are talking in the context of a fund that had chosen not to put its premiums up last year, that had had higher drawings and that was going to go below the statutory safe reserves. The fact is that there was no choice. While I regret it, there was no alternative. The alternative for me to deny it would be to have it challenged in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and risk having a health fund go broke in the interim because of what would have been quite irresponsible actions on my part, had I taken the course of action that the shadow minister seems to be agreeing to.

In the end, the sensible thing is to have a regulatory body that takes the politics out of the matter and looks at it on the merits. It should have been done years ago. That is the whole point of PHIAC. To have a body of experts regulating the industry rather than doing it on some arbitrary political whim, as certainly happened under the Labor Party, is a vast improvement.

talk.start.para: —This is pretty extraordinary. If we want to talk about health policy over the last 13 years, I am more than happy to do so, because I recall that it was the Liberal-National opposition that even went to one election without a health policy. Now they go to elections saying they agree with the Labor Party's health policy, which is Medicare. We do have a health policy which we are very proud of. It is called Medicare. We know that this government's true agenda on health policy is, bit by bit, to destroy Medicare.

speech.para: Returning to the items that we are discussing, the minister says that the issue of regulation of fees should go to a regulatory body. Why is it, Minister, that this bill is actually going to see the complete deregulation of fees? Why is it that we are discussing in this bill not just the moving of responsibility for approval of fees to the Private Health Insurance Administration Council—that is the first part of your moving out of any responsibility for approval of fee increases—but the whole deregulation of fees? The minister did not mention that fact. It will not be the case, according to this bill, that the regulatory body continues to approve health insurance premiums. In fact, the government's intention is to deregulate fee increases altogether so that the minister and the Prime Minister can wash their hands of any responsibility for private health insurance premiums.

talk.start.para: —I cannot let pass the suggestion that we agree with the Labor Party's health policy. It is true that we did go to the 1990 election without a health insurance policy. We certainly did have a health policy, which had issues on health, but it did have a hole in the health insurance area. I would point out that the Labor Party went to the 1996 and 1998 elections without any health policy to speak of. They were tawdry documents that contained errors. They would have cast 30 per cent of the population that relies on private health insurance and the 40 per cent of the population that feel they may want it at some point in the future completely adrift. I am happy to highlight that difference at any point because the Labor Party has picked a dud here.

—I am pleased to see that the previous shadow minister for health has just joined the debate. I have no doubt he will have something to say about the difference between the health policy that Labor took to the 1996 election and the 1998 election and the government's health policy. Labor does support Medicare. It is Labor's policy. Every piece of published polling shows that that is what the public knows too. Why is it that every time you open any one of the national newspapers and look at what the public thinks about which political party gets health right, Labor is always way ahead in the polls? The reason is that, since 1983, Labor has had a very strong health policy that is all about Medicare.

speech.para: The government when in opposition chopped and changed over 25 years. If we look at the Prime Minister's attitude, he has wanted to take the knife to Medicare. He has wanted to destroy Medicare at every turn, until 1996 when he finally read the polls in the newspaper and realised that, if he kept saying that, he would not get elected. So he went to the 1996 election and said, `Now don't worry anybody. Just be comfortable and relax because I won't hurt Medicare.' But now that this government are in office we see, as we see in this legislation that we are debating today, continuous attacks on Medicare. That is really what they are all about. What is most important is that the public know it.

The public know that, in 1996 and in 1998, Labor took very strong policies to the electorate about improving access to public hospitals, about making sure that pensioners who need access to dental care could get it. They know that, as a result of this government's attitude to people who need dental care, that was completely wiped out. That was not mentioned in the 1996 election campaign. When this minister was in opposition and when the Prime Minister was Leader of the Opposition they did not tell the public that they were going to abolish the Commonwealth Dental Program. When they got in they abolished a very important part of health service delivery. It was Labor that intended to put it back, and Labor that promised to put it back in the 1998 health policy. We have a very strong commitment to public hospitals. That is where our priority lies. If this government was seriously committed to Medicare, instead of putting $1½ billion into private health insurance rebates they would have put it into public hospitals.

talk.start.para: —I actually came in here to do House duty. I did not realise everyone was contributing so much to this very important debate. I understand the Minister for Health and Aged Care actually accused the Labor Party of having no policy at the last election. Given that I was the member for Jagajaga's predecessor as the shadow minister for health, I thought I might make a comment or two on that.

speech.para: It is a bit rich for the minister for health to claim that Labor had no policy at the last election, given that he basically had two policies, two promises, on health. The first was the 30 per cent rebate on private health insurance. This 30 per cent rebate cost a massive amount of money—almost $2 billion a year. It was a $2 billion a year announcement made on the day the government released its GST tax package. The minister just disappeared. He could not be found. A minor press release went out on the day, but was the minister for health out there selling this $2 billion new promise on health? No.

You are entitled to ask why the minister for health was not out there selling the Prime Minister's 30 per cent tax rebate. The answer is: it was John Howard's policy; the member for Bennelong's policy. The minister for health knows it is going to be a flop. The minister for health knows that this policy is a scandalous waste of taxpayers' money at a time when the public hospital system could use every extra dollar it obtains.

That was the first policy—the Prime Minister's 30 per cent tax rebate. The second policy was so bad it never even got launched. The second policy was the minister's claim that he would develop a new plan to fix up the problem with gaps; a new plan that he would negotiate with the surgeons. The minister for health has come back into the chamber. I am sure he remembers all the hints that he gave us in the lead-up to election day that he was going to announce a policy on gaps. It was such a good policy he never even got to announce it. They had a meeting of the surgeons in the northern suburbs of Sydney and the surgeons put the kybosh on his policy, so it never even got launched. It is a bit like the minister looking into that mirror and seeing himself when he accuses one of the parties in the election of not having a policy. It was him.

In contrast, Labor's plan at the last election was to put an extra $500 million a year into public hospitals. If we were to ask the people in the gallery today what the biggest problem is with the health system today, I am sure they would say it is the public hospital system. Whether or not we have got private health insurance, if we are sick we rely on our local public hospital or the big teaching hospitals to look after us or our families. It is the public hospital system that we all rely on whether or not we have private health insurance.

This minister for health says that we do not need extra money for the public hospital system because he fixed it in the last Medicare negotiations. Unbelievably, he said on radio during the election campaign that he had fixed the problem in public hospitals through the last Medicare negotiations. If you ask any doctor out there, any patient or any nurse whether there is enough money going into the public hospital system, they will tell you that this government should promise, as Labor has promised, to put extra funding into the public hospital system. That is the priority that the member for Jagajaga has been stressing every day since the last election. Put the money where it is needed, put the money where it will do the most good—that is, in the Australian public hospital system.

talk.start.para: —I made a mistake. I said Labor did not have a policy in 1996 or 1998. I should have said 1993, 1996 and 1998 because in 1993 they actually had a policy but they never delivered on it. They promised new initiatives to contract the private sector to provide elective surgery for public patients on waiting lists. Nothing ever happened. They promised to have private hospitals included in regional health services planning under the Medicare agreements. Nothing happened.

speech.para: Mr Lee interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You are going to hear it a lot more times; it is good. They promised an aged care industry review to examine the adequacy of nursing staff to meet the increasing dependency of those living in hostels. Nothing happened. They promised national rural health programs to focus on expanding rural health centres. Nothing happened. They promised access to Medicare rebates for bone densiometry for women at risk of developing osteoporosis. It did not happen. They promised the establishment of a national health promotion authority. It was never done. They promised the legislative reform of the National Health Act to ensure Australia's commitment to the promotion of health. It did not happen.

speech.para: They promised language services would be provided in public hospitals. It was not delivered on. They promised the establishment of a national health advisory council on ethnic health. It was not done. They promised a continuation of the national health strategy. The national health strategy was wound up. They promised to deliver on a national primary health care policy. It was not done. They promised a national environmental health strategy, and that was never delivered on. So, while they had a health policy, they did nothing between 1993 and 1996 to deliver on it and I should have added that into 1996 and 1998.
Mr Lee interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I apologise to the Labor Party, yes. I will just make a couple of points. First, Medicare is in better shape now than when the government took over in 1996—there is no doubt whatsoever. Had we gone on and not addressed the issues that clearly Labor had had policy fatigue on and found were too difficult for them, then we would be in real difficulty, but Medicare is in better shape than it was three years ago.

speech.para: The opposition also says their policy is all about Medicare, and I actually agree—their policy is all about Medicare. It has nothing about those people who either have or would like to have choice of private health insurance because, in the words of Graham Richardson, the Labor Party is biased against private health insurance.

talk.start.para: —I will be brief, Mr Deputy Speaker, and appeal to the Minister for Health and Aged Care to perhaps consider responding to this particular point: that is, that the particular clause we are considering at the moment takes away from the minister the responsibility of having to approve increases in private health insurance premiums. It is my understanding that in doing this the minister for health will be breaking the Prime Minister's promise.

speech.para: After the 1996 budget the Prime Minister was hit with lots of questions about increases which had been approved in two private health fund premiums. During a doorstop in Brisbane the Prime Minister gave an assurance to the people of Australia that he would ensure that Australians got the full benefit, to the last dollar, of any concession on private health insurance. So the Prime Minister intervened and subsequently required that all increases in health funds had to be approved not only by the minister for health but also by the Treasurer and the Prime Minister himself. The Prime Minister gave an assurance that every future increase in private health fund premiums would have to be approved by the minister for health, the Treasurer and the Prime Minister.

talk.start.para: —It was not a core promise.

—As the member for Jagajaga interjects, it obviously was not a core promise; it was one of these disposable promises. I ask the minister to explain to the House today what has changed since the Prime Minister gave that personal guarantee to all of those Australians out there with private health insurance that he would personally have to approve future increases in premiums.

speech.para: Minister, what has changed since the Prime Minister assured us that he would have to personally vet all future increases in health fund premiums? The Australians out there who have private health insurance know that if the minister and the Prime Minister wash their hands of any responsibility for supervising premiums they will lose the benefit of that rebate. They will be hit by higher premiums which will leave them with having to pay more, irrespective of the government's 30 per cent rebate. So, Minister, please tell us, what has changed since the Prime Minister gave us that personal guarantee? What has changed since the Prime Minister intervened to help you after that budget outbreak in 1996?

talk.start.para: —What the Prime Minister promised was to make health insurance cheaper for Australians, and the fact is today it is cheaper, with the 30 per cent rebate, than when we came to government. That was the promise.

speech.para: And what has happened in the last three years? We have three years more experience. When the Prime Minister made that comment I suspect he did not realise that in 13 years of Labor they had in fact allowed every premium increase to go through without any scrutiny whatsoever. He perhaps did not realise the hypocrisy of the Labor Party, although I have drawn his attention to that.

We are not proposing for the foreseeable future that we will actually keep scrutinising them. The fact is that, under that, we can do it for the foreseeable future. But in the end we now have a health insurance industry that is in better shape, that is more competitive. I know it is a bit harder because of the regulators—
Ms Macklin interjecting—

talk.start.para: —We could get rid of it tomorrow. What I am telling you is that for the foreseeable future we are going to continue to do it. I know the Labor Party has difficulty understanding this, but this is now a more competitive industry that is in better shape, and competition is what will protect the public in the end.

Schedule 3 agreed to.

talk.start.para: —The opposition will not be opposing the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1999 . We consider it an inadequate bill in some ways which I will outline, but it is clearly all that the government is prepared to do in response to the circumstances confronting the domestic shipbuilding industry, and particularly those companies building fast ferries in the face of significant international competition. Obviously we would not wish to stand in the way of legislation which will provide that industry some assistance to compete in the distorted market that is the international shipping market and particularly the international market for fast ferries.

speech.para: It is not our intention, as I said, to oppose the legislation, but we are firmly of the view that the legislation should indicate that the bounties will continue until a new OECD shipbuilding agreement is reached. The current situation is that all of the competitors of the Australian domestic shipbuilding industry—all those people competing with Incat from Tasmania, with the flourishing North Queensland shipbuilders, with Oceanfast and Austal and all those companies building ferries and associated shipping in the Fremantle area—continue to receive assistance assessed by the Shipbuilding Industry Review Panel as approximately double that received by the Australian industry. We are firmly of the view that, until that circumstance is changed, that bounty should continue. We will campaign for that, we will support the industry in its demand for that and, if the voters on a future occasion give us the opportunity, we will do that; but we will not fail to pass this bill. We will not fail to pass this bill because it is the only support on offer. Within the time limitations of that program, I think this has some advantages over the existing bounty scheme. Therefore, I welcome those and indicate that that will be, in some of the principles, the direction in which we would be likely to go.

It is a strange set of circumstances that leads us to this bill. One thing that was not strange was that, just by sheer coincidence, the government announced its intention to renew this bounty in the middle of the election campaign and in an area where it was considered politically beneficial for the government. But why did it have to do that? We had an effective, operating support system. The reason it had to do it was that in the 1996 budget the coalition announced it was going to axe the bounty. It then became apparent that the Senate would not pass a measure to axe the bounty, and the government therefore grudgingly agreed to extend the bounty to June 1999 and set up the inquiry.

One of the ironies of that announcement during the election campaign is that my colleague the then shadow minister for industry and the member for Hotham, now the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, in responding to the government's inadequate announcement, concluded his press release by saying:

Labor looks forward to the Prime Minister's next poll-driven backflip, which will probably involve extending the Book Bounty for the seat of Bendigo. Hopefully this time he will go more than half way.
The member for Hotham got that absolutely right. There was a backflip on the book bounty, it was announced in Bendigo and it was about half what the existing situation is.

With regard to this ships bounty, I think most members of this parliament—perhaps not everybody but most members—would think it would be better if we did not have it. Most members would think that it would be better if the competitors had no bounty and then we would not have a bounty, and our people could be out there competing in a fair market. All the signs are that they would win, but they would have to keep up to the mark to win. They would have to stay efficient to win, they would have to stay effective to win, they would have to manage well, they would have to have R&D, they would have to have good design, they would have to produce good products and they would have to sell them well. That is what we want. But with this sort of bounty, in the context in which the OECD is proceeding with snail-like enthusiasm towards concluding the OECD shipbuilding agreement, we cannot send our industry out to compete in the international marketplace without at least some comparable level of support.

This is not about protecting the domestic industry from competition; our market is wide open. We are talking about a successful, internationally competitive, export based, high technology industry. That is why we find it so disappointing that the government, in its response to the circumstances confronting the industry, has come up with a response—which is fairly typical but nevertheless disappointing—which is that they have done the least they think they can get away with, rather than the most they think they can afford. Why did that come about? Why is it such an awkward compromise in simply extending what had been extended to 1999 for another 12 months with a phase-out—not because anybody seriously believes that by 31 December 2000 there will be an OECD shipbuilding agreement.

I have had the honour of representing this country at the OECD. It does some wonderful research. It is an organisation that does a lot of very important things. Since I had the opportunity to be there, the OECD has grown—new members have been introduced with the opening up of democracy in what used to be called Eastern Europe. But, even with the smaller body with which I dealt, agreement making is a lowest common denominator process. There is significant resistance to an agreement. One of the reasons there is significant resistance to an agreement is that, if there were an agreement which removed the bounties, the Australian industry would defeat many of the European industries. We are already selling into the European market, which they resist very strongly.

I had the opportunity at a meeting to discuss with the Norwegian minister for shipping the competition in the European market. She would not believe that the assistance received by our industry was only that which is in the bounty legislation. She said, `Your industry could not be beating the Norwegian shipbuilding industry in the European market with such a low level of agreement.' I invited her to come to Australia to examine the circumstance but I suspect she has not come here in the subsequent five years, because they do not actually want to know that our industry could beat theirs.

We have to accept that might not be the circumstance forever and that, if we advocate opening up the market so we can have a chance to win, sometimes we will lose. That happens—that is the consequence of open markets—but we have an advantage driven by skill, technology and management and by very skilled, well trained work forces. That is the sort of industry on which Australia should be focusing.

So why did we get such a limited, awkward compromise from the government, such a limp-wristed response? There is no doubt it was a very awkward compromise won in a cabinet that basically does not agree with providing this sort of assistance and so, to get them past the election—because a number of marginal seats are affected when you see where the distribution of employment in this industry is—they therefore papered over the cracks for a limited period. But, if they are pretending that by 31 December 2000 there will be a shipbuilding agreement in place, they are, in my view, living in fantasyland. I hope they are right; I think they are wrong.

If they are wrong, we will have to have some major discussion next year about what is going to be the circumstance for this industry in the international marketplace. I make it very clear that our position, in broad principle, will be that we support an OECD agreement; that we support this government seeking to achieve that agreement and that, if we become the government, we will pursue ratification of such an agreement; but that, in the absence of such an agreement, we will continue to provide effective, targeted bounty support to this industry to enable it to compete in the distorted international marketplace.

We said at the last election we believed that removal of bounty assistance should not occur without ratification of the OECD shipbuilding agreement, which would end all shipbuilding bounties and similar assistance in signatory countries. In a statement we made it clear that overseas measures of the sort to which we are referring are subsidies currently ranging from nine to 25 per cent. That compares with a proposal for Australia of five per cent assistance—not that we think we should be in the competition up at the nine and 25 per cent level—we support the five; it was the previous level.

Of course, in other countries it goes beyond a 25 per cent bounty; there is outright import prohibition. We all know that applies in the United States. The so-called Jones Act in the great, free-trading United States is one of the international trade scandals of the last years of the 20th century—that the United States bans the operation within its borders of ships that are not built in the United States. Successive Australian trade ministers and other ministers, but particularly trade ministers, have made representations to the United States, to be met with embarrassed shuffling of the feet because there is no rationale for this ban. It is a sort of 19th century hangover, but there is no political constituency for change at the moment.

In my view the potential to create that political constituency for change in the United States exists because the need for other parts of the United States economy to become efficient will lead to some demand which will enable such ships to operate within the United States. If time permits I will come back to some other developments which I think may well allow Australian built ships, particularly fast ferries, to get some exposure in the United States by trading from neighbouring countries into the United States in a way that exhibits their superior skill and capacity—if they are good enough; I think they are and the industry thinks they are—and creates a demand in the United States. That is our commitment; that is our view of the international circumstance and the way in which we believe the Australian government should be responding.

How is the Australian government responding? What does this bill do? The explanatory memorandum indicates that this bill provides assistance which will cost, with administration, $82 million over five years, $28.3 million of which is expected to go to construction bounty payments, that is, payments to extend the shipbuilding construction bounty from 1 July 1999 to 1 December at a rate of three per cent and then to establish a phasing arrangement for vessels which are contracted for sale by then and delivered by the end of 2003.

In addition, it is expected to cost $51.5 million to set up a new regime to provide for the payment of a research and development bounty to registered shipbuilders for eligible research and development expenditure at the rate of 50 per cent of innovation expenditure up to a total of two per cent of the eligible construction costs of what is called the `bountiable vessel'. In plain English, it must be research and development to apply only to construction and modification completed on or before 30 June 2004. Therefore, the research and development has to be done over the next 18 months but paid until 30 June 2004. It in effect means that, in addition to assistance with meeting production costs to enable them to compete on the distorted international marketplace, the bounty is designed to encourage the industry to focus more on research and development to stay at the cutting edge of technology, which is where they have been and which has enabled them to succeed, and also to allow design elements to be met through that scheme.

That is the element of the scheme that I support. That is the element of the change that the government has introduced which I think is a positive. They have moved to encourage product research and development and design innovation. Those are the drivers of 21st century economic success. It is very welcome that the government is providing some assistance to this industry for those purposes. Not that it is not an industry that is active in that area—it is, that is why it is successful—but we should be encouraging them to continue to do so.

My concern is that this is taking place in a context of cumulative decline in Australia's assistance to business research and development and to publicly funded research in this country. If the government recognises, as it does and should, that the success of our domestic shipbuilding industry depends upon creativity, knowledge and the application of skill and intellect to the development of new products and new designs of products, why does it not recognise that that is true about industry as a whole and move away from its fetish with cutting assistance to research and development which has led, for the first time since Australia has been collecting this data, to a decline in business investment in research and development? That is a tragedy in a modern economy; an unbelievable outcome in a modern economy. We have a government that is making policy changes that are leading to a reduction in business investment in R&D. Outside this area there is no indication that the government is showing any serious interest in assistance in the area of design, which is also very important.

I want to take some time to look at the nature of this industry and its strengths and its position in the context of a modern international economy such as Australia. It is an industry which, at the end of June 1996, employed 6,672 Australians. That has been a rapid increase in employment. The ship building industry was in long-term decline but since the early 1990s it has turned that around and increased employment to nearly 7,000. It is an industry with very strong market prospects internationally. It is an industry where Australia does very well. The last figures I saw indicated that Australian firms built 40 per cent of all ferries sold in the world in 1997—27 out of 67—and exports of these vessels earned Australia approximately $300 million in 1997. Significantly, it is a very decentralised industry. It is an industry which has a major impact on regional economies in Tasmania, North Queensland and in the Henderson area near Fremantle in Western Australia.

Incat, the very successful international producer of fast ferries, is the largest private sector employer in Tasmania, with over 900 employees, and accounts for more than 10 per cent of that state's export earnings. Its success and the training, skill and innovation that it has developed have spurred other marine industries to develop in the area. We have seen the emergence of an adjacent maritime industrial park, which people hope will generate many more jobs.

We have an industry of increasing importance in North Queensland and we have a very interesting example of a cluster development in shipbuilding in the Henderson area of Western Australia, which is based on an initiative taken nearly 10 years ago to set land aside for that purpose. That was in the eighties, when a lot of people were very doubtful that it would succeed—and I was one of them. But it has succeeded. The impetus that the then state Labor government gave to that development has proved to be very successful. It is an indication of the modern trend towards the so-called cluster development of high technology industries.

It is an industry that is highly competitive internationally. It receives something less than half the rate of assistance available to its European rivals and finds it incredibly hard to break into the other two major developed markets: the United States and Japan. That is not because of a lack of skill or quality but because of market impediments or bans. It is also an industry suffering some consequences of the downturn in Asia. It has a big market selling into Asia. I was associated with initiatives to sell fast ferries into China. There are many parts of South China in which you will find Australian ferries moving between major ports, transporting large numbers of people very successfully. It is a successful export industry for this country.

Significantly, it is very much what we have come to call an industry of the future. When you talk about industries of the future people think you only mean industries that might be created from now, such as some of the exciting new things in biotechnology. They are industries of the future, but industries of the future are also current industries that apply modern science and technology, high levels of knowledge intensity and high levels of skill to existing strengths to create successful new industries, in this instance a successful new manufacturing industry.

It is one of the classics: an industry of the future that has been built, in a sense, from the ruins of the old industry, because the old shipbuilding industry was in what everybody thought was terminal decline. It has now established an effective niche in the international marketplace.

The market for fast ferries is changing, with greater emphasis on size and speed. The Shipbuilding Industry Review Panel predicts that future developments will see 140- to 150-metre catamarans carrying 2,500 passengers and 700 cars. Whatever the nature of that change, their general assessment is that there will be substantial demand for fast ferries in the period to 2005, both replacing older vessels and providing new services.

The most exciting new service option that might open up the United States market would be if relations between Cuba and the United States changed, because Australian fast ferries would be perfectly designed for that rapid transit between Cuba and Florida. There are some people already aware of that option who are looking at buying pier space to service that market, which would blossom the day after it became possible to legally make the trip. The Australian industry could greatly benefit from that and could show to the people in the United States what they are missing out on. These ships are growing in size, they are growing in complexity and they are growing in value per vessel, adding up to a very important modern high technology industry.

It is also very important for the future of our economy because, notwithstanding the very strong economic growth figures of the moment, there is a hole in the heart of our economy, which is the failure of the economy to develop strengths in the knowledge intensity, high skill, high wage industry. When you look at Australia's skill pattern in manufacturing compared to the OECD, we have the lowest level of employment in high-tech manufacturing and we are one of the few in which that percentage is declining. Of the figures I saw we were one of only two, but I am not absolutely sure because the figures did not cover every OECD country. But, as far as I can assess on the figures, and it appears to be the case, Australia has the lowest level and is one of the few, perhaps one of only two, in which that percentage is declining.

Our growth in high technology exports has been very strong. High technology manufacturing and elaborately transformed manufactures are the fastest-growing areas in the world, where relative prices are increasing. But we are losing momentum from the very rapid increase in exports of high technology manufacturing, such as fast ferries, pharmaceuticals, electronics and aerospace.

As we lose momentum there and look increasingly to the very important agricultural and mining industries for our export income and to low technology, low skill strategies, we find ourselves internationally selling into a falling market. The relative prices of low skill manufactured products and low knowledge intensity manufactured products, as well as agriculture and mineral products, are falling. The high skill, high knowledge intensity, high technology industries are where relative prices are rising. To be successful in the medium term we are going to need more focus in that area. One of the worrying signs is that Australia's research and development remains concentrated at the low technology end of manufacturing.

I reiterate: the government has introduced measures with which we disagree. We think they are too limited and they are inadequate. We would have done it differently. We would have done it in a way which we think is more realistic in terms of assisting the industry to compete in the international marketplace in which it finds itself, but we will not be opposing these measures. We are not proposing to amend them. We support some elements of the change—the increased emphasis on research and development and on design—but we think it is very important that the government recognises that this industry of the future, which faces a significantly distorted international marketplace and is an important regional employer, should continue to receive support from Australians for so long as those situations continue so that, if it stays efficient, effective, technologically at the cutting edge and internationally competitive, it can succeed.

Australian taxpayers cannot write a cheque to guarantee that any industry will succeed but they can say, `We will create the circumstances and provide the incentives and assistance to enable you to compete successfully, to enable you to go into the 21st century as a key part of a high skill, high wage, high knowledge intensity, high technology industry creating good jobs for Australians into the next century.'

talk.start.para: —I welcome the opposition's belated support in not opposing the Bounty (Ships) Amendment Bill 1999, but what the member for Fraser overlooks is that the Australian shipbuilding industry supports the government's package of measures. No mind that he wanted to do it differently; the industry supports it. On a national scale, the traditional shipbuilding industry is small compared to other manufacturing industries. However, in Western Australia and in Tasmania—those two states in particular—a new generation of shipbuilders has emerged over the past decade. Today the shipbuilding industry based in my state of Western Australia occupies a significant world market niche in high speed, aluminium hulled ferries. It is a very important component of Western Australian industry and exports.

speech.para: Our expertise in the design and manufacture of high speed passenger and vehicle carrying ferries has made us a world leader. The industry, in particular in Western Australia, is a fascinating case study of the local factors which can contribute to the development of an internationally competitive industry. In a competitive sense, the industry is an example of a growing market where entrepreneurial flair, superior design and technology, and a young, skilled and largely non-unionised work force combine to produce a new type of vessel on greenfield sites. The non-union, flexible labour force is a key element. It is an export oriented industry sector that employs almost 3,000 people across Australia and exports 90 per cent of its product which was valued at about $500 million in 1998.

Why then this legislation which, in effect, extends a government bounty, albeit as a mixture of construction support with innovation support, in a competitive, innovative industry? The answer is that the Australian companies which are leaders in the fast ferry industry at present must be able to keep ahead of the anticipated competition but in a particular time frame. I will elaborate, but we should embrace this legislation against the backdrop of the world shipping scene. Traditionally, the shipbuilding industry around the world has been characterised by a strong degree of government assistance, the prevalence of which is generally associated with strategic and defence considerations, the significance to many nations of exports and the direct employment and multiplier effects of the industry upon the local economy.

The perceived existence of significant beneficial externalities due to the numerous linkages that shipbuilding has with a wide range of related and support industries is also a significant factor in this tradition of national government assistance to shipbuilding industries. The conjunction of the skills and technology necessary to build high quality ships can be of vital importance in promoting other industrial aims. However, there is no doubt that the tendency for governments to provide assistance to shipbuilders has, over the years, led to a distortion of competition among countries and shipbuilding companies alike. Unfair pricing and dumping practices have emerged and the extent of support is said to be far from transparent in many cases.

As a result, in 1989 the United States initiated discussions to provide guidelines for acceptable practices in the shipbuilding industry. This United States initiative resulted in the development of the Agreement Respecting Normal Competitive Conditions in the Commercial Shipbuilding and Repair Industry. The goal of the agreement is:

. . . to establish in a legally binding manner, normal, ie. subsidy and dumping free, competitive conditions in the shipbuilding industries in the OECD countries. In this way it will provide a "level playing field" for nearly 80% of the world shipbuilding industry.

In 1994, the OECD shipbuilding agreement was signed by the USA, the European Union, Japan, Norway and Korea, which, collectively, equates to around 80 per cent of the world shipbuilding capacity. However, the agreement is yet to come into force because, despite support from the USA administration, the US Congress has not yet ratified it. They are being pressured to do so.

From Australia's perspective, this should be put in context. Most of the shipbuilding in the OECD countries which are party to the agreement at this stage is the traditional large scale construction of steel hulled ships, such as tankers, bulk carriers and container ships. The industry is a mature one, the technology associated with constructing steel hulled vessels is mature and economies of scale and scope dominate production and marketing. There is considerable overcapacity in steel shipbuilding. It is against this world market that the Australian shipbuilding industry was able to flourish in the niche market of aluminium fast ferries for passengers and vehicles.

Nevertheless, the Australian shipbuilding industry does operate in the global environment where other governments heavily subsidise their shipbuilding industries and tariff and non-tariff barriers hinder access to potential markets. The high level of government assistance provided to shipbuilding industries in other nations is a major distortion of the global market for ships, but the existence of subsidies overseas does not justify per se the provision of similar assistance in Australia. The importance of this legislation is that it recognises the need of Australian companies to increase the pace and level of innovation, if they are to keep ahead of competition. It allows a time frame for changes to Australia's current bounty arrangements.

The OECD shipping agreement is before the US Congress. That is the last step of ratification required. But the recent developments in the European Union give good grounds to believe that the high subsidies afforded to shipbuilding overseas are all but temporary. The current legislation before the House seeks to provide modest assistance for a limited period of time with a new emphasis on innovation, while the industry seeks to become more competitive by virtue of an increasingly level playing field around the world.

One could point to the tension between the economic benefits of adherence to trade liberalisation concepts, on the one hand, and the existence of a government subsidy for a competitive exporter, on the other. But, first, the bounty is extremely modest, with a total entitlement of five per cent.
