It is sheer folly—an inquiry into airport management and the government removes the last layer of parliamentary scrutiny!

I know the argument that government members will make: that Sydney airport is no different from other airports. But it is different from other airports. They have been privatised; Sydney airport has not been privatised. I do not argue with the removal from the scrutiny of the Joint Statutory Committee on Public Works of the airports that have been privatised but, as I said, Sydney airport has not been privatised. It is 100 per cent in government ownership.

The government did not privatise Sydney airport for understandable reasons, but this government has now given in to the bureaucrats and will let them have unfettered running of the airport. People often complain about the inability to influence parliament. One way is through public hearings of committees of the parliament. This has always been the great strength of the Public Works Committee, especially with reference to airports. Most people accept the need for an airport, but they do not want it in their own backyard—have a look at Badgerys and various other airports.

No airport has generated more controversy over the past decade than Sydney airport. During the public hearing process we always have a huge attendance. We have conducted inquiries at Sydney airport on things ranging from the car parking to the new road system to the sprinkler system to the new stand areas—all the vast range of works that have been going on there. People came to that committee and put their arguments either for or against the proposal. That is what the bureaucrats hate. This is what they have been trying to avoid for many years. They do not want the public to have a say. They want to make their decisions in secret and then impose them on the public.

Another argument I am sure the minister, having been briefed by the bureaucrats, will use is that the Public Works Committee process delays the work. This is an absolute nonsense and anyone from either side of the chamber who has served on the committee, under both Labor and coalition administrations, will know that this is a folly. Because of the importance of the Sydney airport to the Olympics, the committee many years ago took a decision to expedite all work there. At no time have we delayed one aspect of Sydney airport work and absolutely no-one can point to any case where we have delayed any work at all at Sydney airport. We have always given co-current documentation, we have allowed expressions of interest to be called even before the reports have been tabled and we would often have hearings of a Friday or a Monday of a sitting week. Under no circumstances can it be claimed that the committee ever delayed any work. Those who make this claim—as they will—should be forced to produce the evidence.

I have been around long enough to see this attempted bureaucrat takeover before. When Labor was in power, two Labor ministers tried to exempt the Sydney airport from Public Works Committee scrutiny at different times. On one occasion it got as far as our caucus notice paper and it was not until I turned up at the caucus and read it in the notice paper that I knew that this was on—I knew the bureaucrats had been at the minister yet again. We soon got that removed from the caucus paper. I lived through threats from various ministers, but I always stood firm, especially on Sydney airport, because I believe fundamentally that, of all the airports in Australia and all the public works that the Public Works Committee scrutinises, the Sydney airport is the very one in most need of scrutiny.

The bureaucrats associated with the Sydney airport hate the Public Works Committee. They hate having to be accountable. They hate public scrutiny. It will be to the minister's everlasting shame that he has been snowed by the bureaucrats. It is no `Yes Minister' here; it is a weak and compliant minister, a minister not knowing what is happening being snowed by his bureaucrats. The minister may go along with it, he may talk the government members into going along with it and he may force them to vote for it, but do not expect us on this side to vote along with it.

What are we really talking about? What is involved and why is it so important? The Public Works Committee by act of parliament has to examine and report to parliament on every public work in excess of $6 million. The very fact that the bureaucrats have to justify expenditure often means that this committee makes many savings—millions and millions of dollars—that this parliament often never hears anything about. I could go on about the $35 million saved on the Albion decontamination project in Melbourne—that was report No. 6 of 1997—or the $10 million saved on the Australian Geological Survey Organisation project or how, under the chairmanship of the current Minister for Forestry and Conservation, up to $50 million was saved on the east coast armaments depot. This is taxpayers' money that the committee saved.

The committee has a reputation for doing its job and this is what upsets the bureaucrats so much. The bureaucrats want to be answerable to no-one—least of all to parliament. It is not their money; it is the taxpayers' money. So they want to spend it how they like and how dare parliament interfere. Imagine the joy when the bureaucrats knew they had a weak minister in the Minister for Finance and Administration and a compliant minister in the Minister for Transport and Regional Services.

If people want to fully understand the issues involved, they should obtain a copy of the report of the 9 February briefing by the bureaucrats of the Public Works Committee. It is a public document. It is good reading and I recommend it to anyone really wanting to know what we are up against with the bureaucrats. It is all in this report.

How much money are we really talking about? The bureaucrats admitted before the Public Works Committee last month that their borrowing program was $1.45 billion. If they go belly up, who will pick up the tab? Let me quote the chair of the committee, the member for Pearce, who at the 9 February 1999 briefing posed the question to the bureaucrats:
So if you made decisions that created a financial problem there could be an implication in terms of the expenditure of taxpayers' money.
Mr Mrdak, Assistant Secretary, Airports Environment, Department of Transport and Regional Services, on page 16 said:
That is right.

There you have it. You and I, the taxpayers, will be responsible for this $1.45 billion that they are going to borrow. And they want no scrutiny. The minister says that no scrutiny is needed for $1.45 billion of taxpayers' money. In the next two years, in an orgy of spending, this unsupervised group of bureaucrats will spend $700 million of taxpayers' money at Sydney airport and they do not believe and the minister does not believe that they should have any supervision at all; they should just have carte blanche to shovel money at Sydney airport.

This parliament, if it does not vote the measure down, will be complying with rorts and shonky deals. We on this side will push this to the vote because, when the corrupt tendering practices are revealed, when the deals that are done are revealed and when the shoddy work is revealed, it will be on the public record as to who voted to exclude this group of bureaucrats from parliamentary scrutiny.

They cannot run Sydney airport now. You only have to pick up the paper any day of the week and read about Sydney airport, whether it is a radar system, the queues there or whatever. The bureaucrats cannot run Sydney airport now and yet we are going to let them raise $1.45 billion and spend an unsupervised $700 million to paper over the inadequacies and shortcomings of Sydney airport. A more glaring example of dereliction of duty could not be recorded.

It will be on the public record, when the rorts and shonky deals are revealed, as inevitably they will be. I say that because there will be a huge amount of pressure to get Sydney airport completely finished for the Olympics. In that case there will be shonky work done, there will be shonky deals done and there will be millions and millions of dollars spent unsupervised. One day it will all come to light. It will be revealed, and that is what the bureaucrats do not want: they do not want any scrutiny of that at all.

Recently it came to light that, because of shonky deals in relation to the Olympic village, there was an $11 million rort. That was only two weeks ago. When we are talking about $700 million or $1.45 billion, $11 million is really not a lot of money. That $11 million was the result of the pressures to get that housing finished and the deals that had been done there. This group now want to throw $700 million of taxpayers' dollars at Sydney airport in a spending frenzy.

I do not mind their spending the money; it can be justified. I do not object to the $700 million going to finish Sydney airport, but at a time when calls are being made to investigate the management would any person in their right mind let this crowd loose with $700 million? Would they let them loose with absolutely no supervision and remove the one layer of supervision that this crowd has at the moment? The track record of those running Sydney airport is abysmal.

Where in this is the member for Bradfield, the chair of the airport task force? Does he know about this? Where does he stand on this issue? What about the member for Cook, who came into this parliament last night and made a speech about Sydney airport? What about the member for North Sydney, the current Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who had been the chair of the Sydney airport task force, or even the member for Hughes? Has it been discussed in the coalition party room? I bet it has not been discussed there. Where do those members stand on these issues?

When the vote is called—and it will be called because we intend to call it—they will all troop in here and blindly vote with the government. But what will they be voting for? They will be voting, as I will inform each of their constituents, to allow the management of Sydney airport to spend $700 million of their money on schemes over the next two years and to borrow an unsupervised amount of $1.45 billion. It will be too late to come in here then and cry crocodile tears. They will vote to allow Sydney airport's management and its expenditure to be totally unsupervised—always knowing that the taxpayer is the bunny who, at the end of the day, will pick up the tab.
Finally, we have to ask: what would be gained? At the Public Works Committee meeting on 9 February 1999 the member for Oxley, a member of the committee, on page 16, asked:
Specifically what benefits would be gained either practically or economically, in terms of not having to report to this committee?
Ms Hodge, who is legal counsel for Sydney airport, replied:
I suppose management time in the sense that the requirements in the Airport Act are quite onerous and it takes up a lot of management time to comply with those requirements.

That was the reason given: the bureaucrats, who are on thousands of dollars—much more money than what we are on—found it onerous to come before a parliamentary committee. That was their own admission. That is the only reason that they want it: they find it onerous, in terms of their time, to come before a committee. Ms Hodge went on to say:

I go back to my original point of it being another layer of oversight. From a point of principle, one considers whatever competitors are required to comply with, and then we see that there are reasonable grounds for requesting an exemption, also having regard to the two grounds for seeking an exemption under the PWC act.
That was their reason. I then said:
So is it a matter of principle with you? It is not economic or anything, but just principle?
The bureaucrats do not want to spend their time justifying the borrowing of $1.45 billion or the spending of $700 million. They find it onerous. Well, tough.

This is what this whole thing is about. The bureaucrats want to, unsupervised, borrow $1.45 billion and, over the next two years, shovel $700 million into Sydney airport. They want to do it without scrutiny and the last thing they want is a parliamentary committee overseeing them. It is a disgrace that the minister has allowed himself to be snowed.

I have great respect for the minister, whom I have known for many years. I am sure that he was unaware of this. Maybe it was an onerous aspect of his job. I realise that he would have many papers crossing his desk and I know how the bureaucrats can snow ministers who have a very heavy workload.

I say to the minister that it is not too late to reconsider. He need not push it; he can vote with us on this issue and not disallow this motion because it is a very important issue. We hear much about parliamentary scrutiny today. It is important that we have parliamentary scrutiny. We are not talking about small amounts of money; we are talking about huge amounts of money.

The Public Works Committee—and this is no reflection on the current chair or even the former chair—was snowed under with this. The former chair of the committee, now the minister, received a letter which left the minister's office two days before parliament was dissolved, indicating that this course of action was going to be followed. The committee was dissolved when parliament was dissolved. We first became aware of this I think on 8 December at the first meeting of the new committee. We immediately asked for a briefing and we received that briefing at the next meeting of the committee, which was on 9 February. At that time I think it had two days to run—I believe it was a Tuesday—and the motion would have become law two days later. That is why we decided to move this disallowance motion. It is an important motion.

I know how this place works. I know on this side we do not have the numbers and this disallowance motion will probably be voted down. It will be a great tragedy if that happens. We on this side of the House are not going to let go of this matter. We will continue raising the issue. We will raise it in all possible avenues, in the media and with the constituents of members who vote for it. Any member of this federal parliament who votes to let a group of bureaucrats loose on something like Sydney airport, to allow them, unsupervised, to borrow $1.45 billion—$1.45 billion we are talking about!—and to shovel $700 million at Sydney airport in a spending frenzy over the next two years is derelict in their duty.

We should vote for this disallowance motion and we should not proceed with it. I would ask those on the other side, who know that I am right on this matter, to cross the floor and vote with us. Do not let the bureaucrats have a victory. Do not let them get away with it. Stand up for parliament.

talk.start.para: —Order! Is the motion seconded?
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I listened with great interest to the contribution made by the mover of the motion, the honourable member for Throsby. I find it a little sad that, after all these years of serving on the Public Works Committee, which I understand he has contributed to significantly over those years, he should get this particular matter so wrong. I say that in this context. In the course of his remarks, he made reference to the fact that Sydney airport is controversial. Yes, it is controversial. It is controversial because there is a massive amount of building and construction that has been going on in recent times. In the course of that building and construction, there has been a fair degree of inconvenience suffered by the travelling public.

speech.para: The complaints that I get in respect of that are: `When is Sydney Airport Corporation going to finish this work off and make it more convenient? When is there going to be proper access to the taxis? When are you going to be able to get to the car park without getting wet?' The other controversy, which I think was what the honourable member for Throsby was referring to, has absolutely nothing to do with the Sydney Airport Corporation. It is what occurs in the context of flight paths and planes coming in and going on and where they fly over. All honourable members have heard a fair bit about that over the years. If you know anything about Sydney, you know a lot about flight paths. That controversy has absolutely nothing to do with the Sydney Airport Corporation.

He went on to say that here we have $1.5 billion shovelled into shonky deals. I point out to the honourable member for Throsby that all of the works that are being conducted at the present time—that is, the construction works—were approved when Sydney airport was under the umbrella of the Federal Airports Corporation. In the course of putting those proposals for construction work on the international and domestic terminals—the car park and the new bridge that is going over the Georges River—all of that was referred by the Federal Airports Corporation to the Public Works Committee. And it was scrutinised and approved by the honourable member for Throsby and his colleagues.

That proceeded to a point where government determined last year that it needed to corporatise the operation of Sydney airport to ensure that it was placed on a similar footing to the airports that had been sold. The honourable member for Throsby indicated to us that he did not mind that the airports that were sold were not subjected to the Public Works Committee and that they should deal with their construction works and any building programs in a normal, corporate fashion.

But he wants to put the government's instrumentality that has been corporatised into a separate category. He wants them to be subjected in a way in which the competitors at Melbourne, Brisbane and even Canberra are not subjected. He thinks that is appropriate. So he is worried about the shonky shovelling of $1.5 billion into a construction program at Sydney airport, which was scrutinised and approved—it certainly was not knocked over by the Public Works Committee—when the Federal Airports Corporation had the umbrella management of that airport, along with many others. On this occasion they said that, because there has been a change, it is nothing to do with the building program that is there. He wants to say, `This can't happen. This has got to be stopped.'

This was done in a way which is very similar to what Labor did all of these years. Where were you, honourable member for Throsby, when the former government sought to exempt Aerospace Technologies of Australia Ltd; when it sought to exempt the Australian Canned Fruits Corporation; when it sought to exempt the Australian Industry Development Corporation? Multibillions of dollars were in that particular industry bank. Where were you when the former government gave an exemption to the Australian National Railways Corporation? I would have thought the Railways Corporation had a reasonable public works type program. There is a fair bit of construction involved in railways.

Where were you when the former government gave an exemption to the forerunner of that great and wonderful company Telstra, which is rapidly progressing in the services it is providing to all Australians at the present time? It was not a small capital works program when it was Telecom. It was not a small capital public works program when it was the old post and telecommunications organisation. The Labor government gave an exemption then.

Where was the honourable member for Throsby when an exemption was given to the Pipeline Authority? I would have thought the Pipeline Authority could do a bit of construction and get the gas from the Cooper Basin to the people on the eastern seaboard, et cetera. I could go through a list of exemptions a mile long where a legitimate exercise of section 6 of the Public Works Committee Act was undertaken by the then minister of the day for purposes of putting those operations on a proper corporate footing. That is what this government has done. I assure you that I knew about it fully and I fully supported it, despite your trying to make allowances for me—I appreciate that you really did want to be nice to me in saying that I was probably snowed or too busy to know about it.

The government passed legislation—I think the Airports Act was supported by Labor—that provided a mechanism for all airports, including Sydney airport, to have any building and construction program checked through under provisions which are pretty onerous. The provisions require public comment; they require a draft plan to be prepared; they require a building supervisor to ensure that all of those aspects are looked at thoroughly; they require consultations with state and territory governments and with the local government body. None of those provisions are there currently.

They were not there when your committee looked at the Federal Airports Corporation. Consultation with local government or with any other person—with the whole of the community—or consultation with an airline or other user of an airport are provisions that are contained in the Airports Act. Then the draft has to be approved by the minister and then there is a requirement for it to be properly looked at. This is an extremely onerous process.

In seeking to have this exemption thrown out, the honourable member for Throsby wants the Sydney Airport Corporation Ltd to be subjected to all of the things that apply to Melbourne, Brisbane, Perth, Coolangatta, Townsville and all those other airports that the government sold. He wants the Airports Act and its provisions to apply to all those airports and to Sydney Airport Corporation, because that is the way it has been set up, and as well he wants the Public Works Committee to have a go. It has already had a go, and we all know that Sydney airport is going to be sold.

It was going to be sold by the Labor Party, and we have never made any bones about the fact that, as a government, at the appropriate time we will also move to sell. That will be after the noise abatement program—which, if not complete, is almost complete—and insulation of homes and public buildings around Mascot airport has been completed and a decision made on the second Sydney airport. And that has its own controversies attached to it. Those decisions have to be taken, and then the intention is to sell the airport. That is what Labor was proposing and made some moves to do just that.

In that context, you are saying that in the period before it is sold you want doubly onerous provisions put on this corporate body under the Corporations Law: to be required to be out there in a competitive marketplace, to be subjected to all of the provisions of the Corporations Law, and to be required to trade on a level playing field. All of those provisions are there and yet you say, `No, we want to put extra provisions and extra burdens on them.' Why didn't you do that to Telstra? Why didn't you do it to the Commonwealth Bank? Why didn't you do it to the Export Finance and Insurance Corporation and the Health Insurance Commission? Why didn't you do it to the Australian Industry Development Corporation or the Pipeline Authority? Why didn't you do it to all of those bodies that you exempted in your time in government? Because you exercised an appropriate operation of law and an appropriate operation of government by exempting them in those circumstances, and yet you see this as the exception. It simply does not make sense. Let me address some of the other issues—so they do not hang there—about the $1.45 billion that has been poured into this, which is all so shonky.
Mr Hollis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —As anyone who passes through Sydney airport would see—particularly in the international terminal—the program has given a massive upgrade and improvement. Yes, the Olympics are coming and, yes, we want it fully operational—that program is quite extensive. It relates to a number of areas, including the redevelopment of the international freight areas. It relates to the aprons. It relates to the runways, and you will see the bulldozers and the various other pieces of heavy equipment that are out there at the present time. I mentioned the bridge, the car parks and the elevated roadways around the domestic terminal—they account for the best part of $700 million. The other $750 million was simply, in the corporatised fashion, a return of the taxpayers' investment in that airport—that is, a cash payment to the Commonwealth on behalf of the taxpayers for all that the Commonwealth has put into that airport over the years.

speech.para: We hear about them going broke and us picking up the pieces. I have to say to you that we now have a commitment, with $700 million going to improving and upgrading the asset. That is the commitment there. There is another $750 million coming back to the taxpayers of Australia for the money that they put in previously. The last valuation of Sydney airport I recall seeing was somewhere in the vicinity of $4 billion, so there is a reasonable debt to equity level. If you look at the value of the first three airports that were sold, the taxpayers got a return of something like $3.3 billion, so I think it is a reasonable sort of approach.

There is very much a business like approach to the operation of that airport—not the take-offs and the landings and the flight paths and the control towers, which Sydney Airport Corporation does not control—and to the provision of services inside the terminal. Whether it be the retail outlets or other services, I can say that there is a massive amount of work going on which I inspected just before Christmas. It would be well worth while for all honourable members who are interested to have a look, and I would be happy to arrange it. The work is about such things as the baggage underneath, about the number of windows for people to get their tickets checked through and for their baggage over the counter. All of it is to ensure that there is an efficient operation in the lead-up to the Olympics.

So what we see here is a rather silly approach to set aside something that successive governments have done over a number of years. In that context, as I say, the scrutiny is quite considerable. Let me just say that, in terms of what is the management, there is a board. That board of course must report to the minister—in this case as the shareholding minister, to me. How does the parliament get scrutiny? Ministers of the Crown, as the honourable members opposite would know, are always accountable to the parliament for any matter that might be raised in here or through any of the other processes of parliament, and I accept that responsibility.

There are times, I have to say, where I would be delighted to see the Public Works Committee take a good look at some of the areas of government, and I am happy to talk to the honourable members about that at some point in time. But in this case, please, put this company on the same footing as the other airports, its competitors. Do what successive governments have done: give them the opportunity that the Corporations Law is designed for in allowing them to trade profitably, to put a return into the taxpayers and to provide that service in the most efficient possible way in terms of the improvements that that $700 million is going into.

How is it controlled? The bulk of the construction is fixed lump-sum contracts. You would probably be aware of this from the process of examining it in the days when the Federal Airports Corporation had control of it. There are bonuses for early completion—there is nothing unusual about that. If we can get them there sooner rather than later, and have the operation going more efficiently sooner rather than later, with the opportunity to trade better, that is what we would want. There are liquidated damages for late completion. That is the protection that has been built in to it.

There is a project manager and audits that are being independently conducted on the various stages of progress of the construction projects, and that audit has been conducted by Findlay Consultants on a quarterly basis. They report their findings to the board and the board reports to me.

So there is a pretty fair mechanism there; it is called the Airports Act. It is probably more onerous than anything that the Public Works Committee was capable of injecting into this particular area because of the strict liability that attaches to it. That puts Sydney airport on the same basis as all the other airports in Australia which it must compete against. What we have here is, sadly, I think, a complete misunderstanding, despite the years of service by the honourable member for Throsby. There is no need in these circumstances for this to occur. The controls are in place. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the outset, can I assure the Minister for Finance and Administration that it is not a misunderstanding by the member for Throsby, your own chair of the Public Works Committee, me or any other member who has been appointed by this parliament to serve on the Public Works Committee.

speech.para: I find rather alarming that at the very beginning of this debate, in the minister's reply to the motion as moved by the honourable member for Throsby, he gave us a five-minute rendition of where he was wrong rather than saying where we believe the action was wrong. I also find it rather alarming that we have the minister for finance get up in this parliament and admit to us and the gallery that he does not know the difference between privatisation and corporatisation.

The other airports he is referring to, and with which he wishes to put the Sydney airport on a level playing field, are privatised, which is quite different from what Sydney is at this moment. Sydney is not privatised. Sydney is still 100 per cent owned by the people of this country. To have a minister for finance get up and say, `Well, really, why didn't the Labor Party or the Public Works Committee object when all of these other areas were privatised?' The Public Works Committee was not involved in it. The fact of the matter is that it is not a debate on privatisation; it is a debate on how this regulation was pushed through to exclude the Public Works Committee.

In saying that, I think one has to look at the history of how it did come about. As everyone would realise, the Public Works Committee, as constituted, was first brought into this House in 1913. It was in 1913 that our predecessors decided that the expenditure of taxpayers' pounds, as it was then, had to have greater scrutiny than it had had up until that date. So, in 1913, after a very lengthy debate, the parliament of Australia set up a Public Works Committee so that it could become the guardian of the taxpayers' dollars. From 1913, the power of the Public Works Committee has been increased. We have now, in 1999, this minister and this Prime Minister wanting to take away the power of the Public Works Committee. This is the first step of many in which we will see implementations of this sort come about.

We on this side of the House are saying, `There has got to come a stage when you draw the line.' This is a stage in the public works where we as parliamentarians believe the line must be drawn. Mr Deputy Speaker, let me now take you through the history of how and why this came about. We have, as I said, a Public Works Committee already resurrected, a Public Works Committee that has been praised by countless ministers, whether they be the minister for finance leaving the House, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services or the Minister for Defence—and I might add that I have only just been appointed to it.

We have had countless reports since 1916, when the very first document was laid in this House, the first report of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, which I have researched. I might add for the benefit of the minister leaving the House that the building of Sydney airport was not started until 1920, yet the power of this committee was already in existence; it tabled its first report four years before Sydney airport even came onto the planning boards. Yet now we want to take the power away from an investigating committee guarding the taxpayers' dollars.

I know our chair agrees with us, because it is a very hardworking, bipartisan committee. It occurred not through her fault or our fault—we are not blaming past committees or present committees; we are blaming the system. On 28 August 1998, the current minister for finance wrote to the then chairman of the Public Works Committee and said, `I wish to now withdraw, or put into a regulation so that I can withdraw, the power of the Public Works Committee investigating anything to do with Sydney airport,' or words to that effect. He said:

The Airports Act, and the regulations made under it, subject airport operators to stringent land use, planning and building controls. These include requirements that a Commonwealth Government-appointed airport building controller. . .

Fair enough. He wanted to put that through and he wrote to the chairman of the Public Works Committee. But what the minister failed to tell those who are listening to this debate, and those who are sitting in this parliament now as part of this debate, is that when that letter was written to Mr Wilson Tuckey on 28 August 1998 the Public Works Committee did not meet. The parliament was prorogued because of the election.

The Public Works Committee then had to be resurrected by this parliament. It was not resurrected as a committee until something like 9 December. What did we have as the first item of business when that new committee was formed under our current chair, the honourable member for Pearce? We had a motion before us stating that this power was going to be removed from the Public Works Committee because, after all, the Minister for Finance and Administration wrote to Mr Tuckey on 28 August and he did not get a reply. The Public Works Committee dealt with that matter very quickly. I commend the chair of the Public Works Committee on how quickly she did put a letter together, which was sent to the parliamentary secretary on 10 December. I quote from part of that letter:
I refer to the letter from the Minister for Finance and Administration, the Hon John Fahey. . .
At its first meeting, the Committee—
us, the Public Works Committee—

resolved that I write to you to request a full briefing on this proposal and the extent to which any procedures under the Airports Act 1996 require a full public consultation process before new works can commence. Committee members were also concerned that the necessary amendments to the Public Works Regulations were tabled in the House on 23 November, without—
I repeat `without'—
further reference to the Committee and that these amendments will be in force at the end of the first sitting week in 1999 unless a disallowance motion is moved and carried.

Committee members are reluctant to relinquish their scrutiny role in relation to major airports, as this provides the only accessible avenue for public examination of such proposals and would appreciate an opportunity to discuss this with you. It would be appreciated if a meeting could be arranged before the expiration of the disallowance period. . .

The letter was signed by the chair, Judi Moylan. We then had a letter back from Mr Slipper on 7 January, saying, `I'm sorry, Judi, but you actually wrote to the wrong person.' It was not through any fault of our own. We were advised that the committee falls under the direct responsibility of Minister Fahey and that it was appropriate that the committee obtain a briefing from Mr Fahey's office.

Immediately then, on 13 January, we received another letter, from Minister Fahey, stating that Mr Slipper, his parliamentary secretary, had passed it on to him. He noted our concerns in relation to the timing of these amendments. He then stated:
However as your letter notes, I wrote to the then Chairman of the Committee on 28 August 1998 advising of the Government's intention to amend the PWC Regulations to exempt the Airport Corporation.
As airport lessees, these companies are subject to the Airports Act 1996 (the Airports Act). . .

That puts in some chronological order why we in the Public Works Committee objected. In the first place, the committee was not resurrected; there was no committee. In the second place, when the first letter was written, there was no reply, because the then chairman had no right to reply as the parliament had been dissolved. Yet it was allowed to be processed through Minister Fahey into Exec utive Council, knowing full well—the bureaucrats knew it as well—that the committee was not meeting until the day after this matter was to go to Executive Council.

That is an affront to any committee of this parliament. It is not just an affront to me, as an opposition Labor person, or to the honourable member for Throsby, as a past chairman, or even to our existing chair. I think it is an insult, even to the current chair of the Public Works Committee, to think that action could possibly be taken, bearing in mind that we had an election in October. We know the committee had not been formed, but at least there could have been some discussion to the effect that, `We're going to push through with this regulation and we're going to make sure that in future the Public Works Committee no longer has control over any action that goes on in the expenditure of taxpayers' dollars or their dollars in Sydney airport.'

I believe that consultation should have occurred then. It did not occur, and I am sorry for that. I believe that is why we felt so intensely about this matter. And in saying `we', I do not just refer to those on this side of the House; I refer to `we' collectively, meaning the Public Works Committee. I reiterate that point by referring to the evidence of 9 February, mentioned by the honourable member for Throsby, which clearly expresses the concerns of so many of the members sitting around the table on that day, following the information that was supplied to us by the people who came in to report.

Both Minister Fahey in his reply to the honourable member for Throsby and the bureaucrats who gave evidence that day kept referring repeatedly to the act of 1996—the Airports Act. Our chair reminded us—she had the document there that day; a very thick document—that she had gone right through it. She said, `Where is there scrutiny of our taxpayers' dollars?' `Oh, but we're now governed by the Airports Act.' Madam Deputy Speaker, as you would know, and as every member of this parliament would know, we had before us an amendment to that act last night, and this parliament stifled debate and refused to allow 12-odd speakers from this side of the House to debate the issue.

Already, there is going to be change to a regulation which allows the Public Works Committee to scrutinise taxpayers' dollars being spent on Sydney airport because we have got this wonderful Airports Act that was put in place in 1996 and it is already going to govern us. An amendment to the Airports Act was before the House last night and the government would not even allow us to debate the bill. All of our speakers were here, ready to debate the bill, and the debate was gagged. How many more amendments to this legislation are going to be introduced? During this time, we will have meeting after meeting where the Public Works Committee will not be able to scrutinise the expenditure of taxpayers' dollars.

I believe that in reality what the government is currently attempting to hide is any scrutiny by the public and the parliament. This is why I keep referring back to the Public Works Committee. Having looked at the history of the Public Works Committee, it would be one of the most senior committees, having regard to years of service to this parliament.

When I researched the reports of previous public works committees under different chairmen over a period of time, nowhere did I find criticism of the actions of the Public Works Committee. When we are dealing with Sydney airport, I have only to refer to the 1998 report under the then chairman, now the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. The report of the committee stated:

The FAC advised the Committee of a proposal to upgrade the airport power supply capacity at the Sydney international terminal at a cost of $5.3 million. The Committee resolved that the matter did not require referral.
They wanted to act in such a manner that the work would not be delayed. In the minister's response, he stated:
Sydney international airport will be the gateway to the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. . .

He went on to talk about the additional facilities, what would be required, and appreciating the fact that the then Public Works Committee had investigated the different works. I have not been able to read or research one report where the Public Works Committee, present or past, has been condemned for delaying any action. In fact, when members of our committee specifically asked, `Could you find or provide a precedent where you have been delayed or held up because you have had to appear before the Public Works Committee?' they said, `No, we have not been able to find that.' Even though, in good faith, their corporation had only been there since July last year, they could not find any precedent where the Public Works Committee had at any time delayed them. Even my colleague the honourable member for Mallee said:

We have gone out of our way to not impede the progress of what quite rightly has to be hasty progress, particularly if it is Sydney airport and Tullamarine in Melbourne. We have approved concurrent documentation, made definitions about repetitive work in order to facilitate. But we are being asked to forsake what we think is a very important function of this committee to provide public scrutiny of activities at airports.
The honourable member for Mallee went on to say in that evidence:
I am not all that keen on agreeing to forsake it yet. I have not heard any convincing argument that sways me.

We have not heard any convincing argument to date that will persuade us. During that hearing I repeatedly asked, as did the chairman—naturally I had to ask the secretary because the chairman, like myself, had just joined the committee—how many meetings the Public Works Committee had held since the receipt of the letter dated 28 August. The answer was, again, none. The first was when it was brought to our attention and action was taken straight away. Our chairman—I feel sure the honourable member for Pearce will speak after me—stated quite clearly:

The concern of this committee is that it is charged with scrutinising government expenditure on behalf of the taxpayer and that the process that it goes through under the Airports Act is not that kind of scrutiny.
It is now going to be taken away from us. She continued:
We want to be convinced that under the Airports Act there is that kind of scrutiny of the expenditure of public funds—that is, taxpayers' dollars . . .
Our chairman went on to say:

. . . and we do not see anything. I got the act yesterday and I have been through it. I cannot see anything that provides us with that level of satisfaction that there is proper scrutiny of the expenditure of government funding by taking it out of the Public Works Committee and allowing it to be subject purely to the Airports Act. That is what we are trying to establish. Is this a correct summation?
The honourable member for Herbert asked:
Can I also confirm that in fact it is the taxpayer who meets any liabilities that might arise in the trading of this operation?
Mr Mrdak replied:

Yes, to the extent that as a corporate entity, as the shareholder-owner, the Commonwealth is there. But as has been the case with these things, the Commonwealth does not provide guarantees of funding or anything like that. The corporation has to borrow the money . . .

But that is not the point. The point of the matter is that, if there is any failure or there are to be any problems, at this stage—the airport not being privatised—it is the Commonwealth, the taxpayers, who are going to bear the burden if there are any mistakes in the future. What we are saying as a Public Works Committee is that we are there to assist. We are not there to try to halt or delay. More importantly, we are also elected by this parliament to scrutinise the expenditure of the dollars. That is why we have moved in this House that the regulation be disallowed. I believe all fair-thinking members of parliament will agree with us and vote with us on this issue. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It is unfortunate that the opposition has sought to use this disallowance motion for an exercise in a bit of crude politicking. One of the outstanding features of the Public Works Committee has been the truly bipartisan nature of its work, which has served the public well under both parties. I sincerely hope that, under my chairmanship, this tradition can continue in the interests of the public. I do not think it was the intention of the member for Throsby to take this issue quite so far, but I think obviously some in his party have seen an opportunity to engage in politics.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I take that as a personal affront. There has been only one other speaker on this matter from this side of the House. I have not chosen to be political and I would ask the honourable member for Pearce to withdraw that comment. I believe that reflects on my character.
—Member for Prospect, what is your point of order?
—That is my point of order. I have asked for a withdrawal. I believe the statement that has been made has implied that, in some shonky way, I have tried to politicise this motion.
—There is no point of order.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, on the point of order: the honourable member has reflected on the intent and motivation of, I think, Mr Hollis in the statement, suggesting that he was acting on behalf of others. That is a most serious allegation, which should be moved in a substantive way. It is unparliamentary and reflects on the member.
—I do not believe there is a point of order.

—There was no intention to reflect on the member for Throsby in the way that has been suggested. Clearly, there are some precedents here. It is not as though this regulation foreshadows some new or extraordinary process. Members opposite know full well that the Public Works Committee Act provides for this exemption under certain situations and there is established precedent. For the record, I quote from section 6A(3) of the Public Works Committee Act:

speech.para: Where the Governor-General is satisfied that an authority of the Commonwealth is engaging in trading or other activities, or is providing services, in competition with another body or other bodies, or with persons, the Governor-General may make regulations declaring that this Act does not apply to that authority.

The Sydney airport issue clearly meets this criteria. The committee initially did express some concern—and I think that was reasonable—about the lack of time to consider this matter. But, to be fair, the Minister for Finance and Administration did write to the committee on 28 August 1998, which provided more than ample notice in anyone's language. We all know that, despite that, an intervening election—

talk.start.para: —There was no committee in existence.

—Excuse me, I allowed you to have your say. We know that an intervening election did create a delay in the matter being considered by the committee, but to suggest that the minister deliberately tried to shovel this through without going through the processes is pushing the envelope.

speech.para: I remind members opposite that the act does not require that the committee itself be consulted on a decision to exclude a corporatised body from the act. However, it is a courtesy that the minister did extend to the committee almost six months ago. I agree with the member for Throsby on the need for the public to become involved in these matters that clearly affect many people in the electorates, but the Airports Act does have an extensive consultation provision, as the minister quite rightly outlined in his speech to the House a short time ago.

One can only wonder what the agenda is here for attempting to disallow these regulations and exempt the now corporatised Sydney airport from examination by the Public Works Committee. The member for Throsby knows perfectly well, as do others on that side, that his party set the precedent for corporatised entities to be excluded when they used the same procedures in exempting other corporatised bodies.

I know that the member for Throsby has a very fine record of service on the Public Works Committee and that he is genuinely committed to serving the public interest. That is understood. I have heard many people speak well of him. But the fact is that 24 government corporations have been subject to this regulation which exempted them from the Public Works Act. Notable amongst these are Australia Post and the Commonwealth Bank. The minister made reference to a number of other corporatised entities—Telstra, the Pipeline Authority and so on. As I said, there is an extensive list. I think the list the minister provided to me covered about 24 government corporations.

Most of these 24 corporations that have been exempted were exempted during Labor's 13 years in government. So it is a crazy notion to suggest that when they did it it was okay and that when this government seeks to do the same thing in the interests of efficiency there is something wrong with it. Considering that the minister, in good faith—before I was chairman of the Public Works Committee—advised the committee of the government's intention to do this, I think it is a bit rich to say that he is deliberately trying to stop the proper scrutiny of this process through the Public Works Committee.

The member for Throsby also raised the issue of the raising of capital. That is, I understand, a matter that is outside the scope of this committee. The committee's responsibility is to scrutinise the actual expenditure by government on buildings and other infrastructure, so clearly that is a bit of a red herring. It really is not an issue in this particular discussion.

Despite the fact that, under a Labor government, around 24 corporations were subject to this regulation, it is quite proper that the Public Works Committee maintains a strong role in scrutinising government spending on major public works. However, we have the precedent, as I said. When a corporatised entity such as Sydney airport already has to meet public interest requirements under another act—and in this case it is the Airports Act 1996—continuing to impose a second tier of scrutiny smacks of bureaucratic processes gone mad. It is just crazy. It is inefficient.

This government is working toward greater levels of efficiency in the conduct of our business—something governments have been asking the private corporations to address for at least a decade that I am aware of. If we expect the private sector to improve its productivity and efficiency, surely government should take its own medicine and ensure that sensible procedures produce greater efficiency and effectiveness without compromising public interest. That is the key issue. We are here to ensure that public interest is not compromised. I believe that, with the provi sion of the Airports Act 1996, public interest is covered.

While the hardworking members of the Public Works Committee have made a strong commitment to ensure that work at Sydney airport is carried out without delay, exposing this corporation to several tiers of scrutiny over and above that necessary to serve public interest is very wasteful of both time and money. There is no criticism either implied or intended of the work of the committee. Historically, the members of this committee have an impeccable record of doing everything in their power to ensure that projects, particularly in relation to Sydney airport, are completed on time. The member for Mallee has talked to me about this on a number of occasions, and I have heard him speak strongly in the committee in favour of the committee ensuring that work is not delayed, particularly in relation to Sydney airport. Along with other committee members, he has strongly expressed that point of view.

The Airports Act is very stringent in the planning and environmental controls it requires of airport operators. Airports are some of the most highly regulated land users. There is a lengthy procedure under the act that sets out the process for airport development, and there is a requirement for the minister to consider all the public submissions in relation to work on airports and to approve or refuse the plan, as the case may be. So there is a very strong requirement for public submissions across a range of interests in the community, and public interest is served under the current Airports Act in that regard.

As I said before, the Public Works Committee has undertaken its work in a constructive, bipartisan manner, demonstrating to the public the very considerable benefits of the committee system which operates in this parliament. It is one area where the public can see the benefit of parties working together in the public interest. It is to be hoped that commonsense will prevail and that this cooperative approach will continue to dominate the work of this committee. That is certainly my hope and my aim.

To date, developments at the Sydney airport have been able to be carried out very effi ciently, and the members of this committee have performed valuable public service in the scrutiny of these projects. Airports have moved, as have many other government owned enterprises, toward private ownership, and they do operate on a commercial basis. Airports are now regulated by the Airports Act 1996. Sydney Airport Corporation now falls into the category of a private company with the government as a sole shareholder.

The Public Works Act has provision to recognise that once a government owned body is corporatised—and I say again that the Public Works Act has that provision—it is competing directly with private entities. Layers of unnecessary procedures place them at a commercial disadvantage. In attempting to disallow these regulations, the opposition is really moving backward because most of the 24 exemptions took place under their 13 years in government.

The fact that members on the other side now say that Sydney airport is something different from the previous corporatised entities that have been subject to the Public Works Committee Act exemption and that they now oppose these regulations gives the public reason really to question the sincerity of a motion like this and to recognise it for what it is. Clearly, as I say, there is precedence set there. There is an act which brings this under public scrutiny, and the contemporary commercial reality demands that Sydney Airport Corporation be placed on an even footing so that it can compete with other operators without unnecessary layers of procedure which do not add to or enhance the important element of public scrutiny.

So there is no point in going through a hollow exercise for the sake of it, when it serves no purpose in enhancing that process of proper public scrutiny of this work, when it is covered under another act. That is a very important point to be made in the debate today. The government is confident that, in the case of Sydney airport, the public interest is protected by the provisions of the Airports Act 1996—which, the minister reminded all in the House in the course of his speech, was supported by members of the opposition.

talk.start.para: —It was amended last night.

—Well, acts are amended from time to time; that is not an usual situation. You did it. When your party was in government, you would have amended acts. That does not mean that there is not the level of public scrutiny under that act. It does not mean anything on its own: there may be minor amendments with no relevance in terms of the public scrutiny aspect of the Airports Act in relation to the matter that we are debating in the House today. As I said, the Public Works Committee Act, for as long as it has been in operation—or probably not since the time it was first established; I am sure that that was a later change—has had provision to recognise that, once a government owned body is corporatised, it is competing directly with private entities and that layers of unnecessary procedures place them at a commercial disadvantage. It is not necessary for us to be going through this process today, because that level of scrutiny does exist.

(Madam Deputy Speaker—Mrs D.M. Kelly)
