talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 8 February 1999:

question.para: (1) How many area consultative committees (a) were operating before 2 March 1996 and (b) are operating in February 1999.
(2) What is the (a) name, (b) contact address and (c) telephone number of the (i) chairperson and (ii) executive officer of each area consultative committee.
(3) What levels of financial and other support (a) does his Department provide and (b) did the Department's predecessor provide before 2 March 1996 to each area consultative committee.
(4) What are the terms of each area consultative committee's charter for operation and responsibilities.
(5) Have the terms of the charters varied since 2 March 1996; if so, how.

(6) Have area consultative committees been given responsibility to collect data on regional skills shortages and job vacancies; if so, (a) what responsibility, (b) how successful has been the data collection, (c) how is the data made available to the public and (d) how is the data incorporated in a national information system.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (2) Detailed list has been provided to the Table Office.

(3)(a) An allocation this financial year of $7 million has been provided for Area Consultative Committee (ACC) operations. Actual funding of individual ACCs varies based on consideration of the particular needs of each ACC, for example allowance is made for the additional meeting and travel costs incurred in the more remote and larger ACC regions.

In addition, $1.2 million has also been provided nationally to allow ACCs to promote themselves within their local communities and to assist them to disseminate information to the local community and employers about the operation of the Job Network.

The Department of Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business obviously also has close working relationships with ACCs. ACCs are thereby provided with ongoing support from departmental officers with, for example, advice on departmental and government programs and policies, assistance with a variety of administrative, operational and planning matters and information on labour market trends. A national ACC Web Site is also maintained by the department with developments currently being undertaken to enhance the site to improve inter ACC communication.

(3) (b) For the 1995/96 financial year national operational expenditure on ACCs was $1.8 million. A further $7.7 million was provided for the employment of officers to the ACC to assist in the conduct of ACC Jobs Drives. In the main these officers were outposted from the then department through a Memorandum of Understanding with the ACC. At that time a number of ACCs operated from Commonwealth premises free of charge. Departmental officers also assisted and operated closely with ACCs in conducting Jobs Drives.
(4) Copy of the charter for Area Consultative Committees has been provided to the Table office.

(5) The current charter was developed in April 1998. The terms of the charter outline the role of area consultative committees for the period 1 July 1998 to 30 June 2001. The charter calls for a three year regional strategic plan for ACCs to enable the development of more effective job market and employment training strategies for their regions. The charter reflects ACCs' role in providing a mechanism for regional consultation, identifying appropriate project activity under the Government's Regional Assistance Program, promoting a range of Government-wide initiatives and in providing feedback and advice to Government on these programs and policies.

(6) No formal role has been assigned to ACCs to collect data on regional skill shortages and job vacancies. ACCs report broadly on the impact of Job Network in an advisory function. Individual ACCs may undertake data collection for use at the regional level to facilitate their role in supporting Job Network on a regional basis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 February 1999:

question.para: On 20 January 1999, did an F-111 aircraft perform a low-level fly-past around Point Danger on the Queensland-New South Wales border and then past the surf beaches to the north before climbing steeply as it approached high-rise buildings further north; if so, (a) was the manoeuvre performed at very low altitudes a few hundred metres from the shore-line, (b) how many similar fly-pasts were performed, (c) how many aircraft were involved, (d) who authorised each flight, (e) what military purpose did each flight meet, (f) what safety precautions were taken and (g) how close to Coolangatta Airport were the flights.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: No.

(a) The aircraft did not perform a low-level fly past. It was flying between 100 feet and 200 feet above sea level and two miles off the coast, when, abeam Coolangatta, it was required to climb to 6000 feet and track West.
None.
(c) One.
(d) Executive Officer No 1 Squadron, RAAF Amberley.

(e) The aircraft, one of five F111s flying a standard flight route from Evans Head Air Weapons Range to RAAF Amberley, via Brisbane Airport to conduct Instrument Landing System approach training, encountered a higher fuel usage than planned and requested an amended Air Traffic Control (ATC) clearance direct to Amberley, from a position abeam Coolangatta. ATC approval was given, with the proviso that the aircraft be at 6000 feet altitude before crossing the coast. The crew then conducted a rapid climb before returning by the shortest route to Amberley.
(f) The flight was conducted strictly in accordance with approved and authorised operational requirements and safety precautions. All RAAF and ATC instructions were adhered to.
(g) Two miles.
